title: 10 Figure Skating Injuries
text:
Figure Skating Expert By Jo Ann Schneider Farris 
Listed below are 10 injuries that occur from ice skating. These injuries happen to recreational ice skaters and serious figure skaters. Some of these injuries happen due to falling, but other injuries could happen because of stress to muscles and joints. Ice Skating May Cause Injuries. Photo by Craftvision / E+ Collection / Getty Images Bruises, Scrapes, and Cuts 
Many figure skating injuries happen because of a fall, and most falls do not cause anything worse than a bruise. A skater may also get cut or scraped. Bruises and cuts and scrapes are usually not serious injuries. 
Bruise Treatment - From About.com First Aid 
continue reading below our video Understanding Baseball Concussions 
The most serious type of figure skating injury is a concussion, and minor blows to the head that occur during skating practice or competitions should not be taken lightly. Figure skaters and their parents need to be aware that concussions can have serious or long-term effects. Cup of China 2014 Figure Skaters Competed After a Serious Collision Knee Injuries 
Knee injuries in skating sometimes happen because jumps, landings, and spins cause high impact to the knee, and sometimes skaters fall on their knees. Certain figure skating moves may also cause knee strain or injury. 
Some knee injuries can be serious, and some knee injuries heal quickly while other knee injuries take a long time to heal. Rest and ice may be all that is required for some knee injuries, but serious knee injuries may require seeing a physician. When to See a Doctor for Knee Pain - From About.com Sports Medicine Tendonitis 
Tendonitis can be caused by excessive jumping or by skating boots that are too stiff or have poor support. Tendonitis is a serious injury. Figure skaters may be required to rest the injured foot and may need medical attention. Tendonitis and tendinopathy: Tendon injuries caused by inflammation and overuse - From About.com Sports Medicine Pulled or Sore Muscles 
Ice skating causes an individual to use muscles he or she may not use in ordinary activities, so there is a chance that certain muscles may be pulled or become sore. Warming up before skating can help prevent pulled muscles. 
How To Treat a Pulled Muscle - From About.com Orthopedics Broken Bones and Stress Fractures 
Any figure skater can break a bone and it can happen at the most unexpected time. Such an injury can happen to hands, arms, legs, or feet if an ice skater falls in the wrong way and suddenly. Treatment varies from simple rest and protection of the fracture to surgical procedures. 
Stress fractures gradually happen. Some figure skaters put repetitive trauma on their bones due to jumping and falling. The body cannot keep up and a fracture eventually occurs. This is not a sudden injury, but gradually worsens over time. All About Broken Bones - Learn About Fractures and Treatments of these Injuries - From About.com Orthopedics Broken Teeth 
There have been occasions when ice skaters fall forward suddenly and hit the mouth and teeth on the ice. When such a traumatic injury occurs, a tooth may break or chip. If this occurs, the injured skater must get to a dentist immediately for emergency treatment. What You Need to Know When You Have a Broken or Cracked Toothâ€‹ - From About.com Dentistry Plantar Fasciitis 
Too many hard landings can inflame the tissue band that connects the heel bone to the base of the toes. Plantar Fasciitis can cause severe and nagging pain that a skater will feel under the heel. 
Physical therapy may be required to help stretch a skater's plantar fascia and strengthen the lower leg muscles and athletic tape may help support the bottom of the injured foot. How to Prevent Plantar Fasciitis From Developing - From About.com Ergonomics Shin Splints 
Shin splints, pain around the shins, can happen to figure skaters due to pressure from the skating boot top and strain to the calf muscles and because of repeated stress placed on the lower leg, Some skaters suffer from shin splints due to skating in boots that are broken down. Learn the causes, treatments and prevention for shin pain from shin splints - From About.com Sports Medicine Bunions, Calluses, Corns, Blisters, and Heel Spurs 
Many foot problems that happen to ice skaters such as blisters, bunions, corns, calluses, and heel spurs may develop due to skating boots that do not fit or because socks or tights that are not straight inside skating boots. Protective pads for feet can be purchased at drug stores that will make the feet caused by irritation more comfortable.
